comments.commentBody: Knowledge isn't power in politics, but the ability to connive and scheme and craftily exploit public ignorance is, and the conservatives have done a masterful job of it for several decades.

This cease fire is welcome, and Secretary of State Kerry and UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon both deserve credit for their efforts.

Anyone who looks at this conflict and sees only civilian casualties, however, is willfully blind.

This conflict is not just about Israel, Palestinians, Gaza, Hamas, rockets or tunnels. It is about the threat posed by Islamic extremists, not only to Israel, but to all moderate Arab nations, governments and people in the Middle East. That is why Egypt, Jordan and Saudi Arabia no longer support Hamas.

While Israel may confront Hamas rocket attacks today, there is every indication that it will be be Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia and other countries in the Middle East facing attacks from Hamas, the Islamic Brotherhood, ISIS, or Al Qaeda tomorrow. Anyone who doubts that should ask Iraqis in Mosul how much they like seeing the foreign troops of Isis beheading Iraqi captives and demolishing even Islamic religious sites.

This conflict is also about the ongoing threat of terrorist attacks by Islamic extremists against nations, governments and people worldwide. Al Qaeda's attacks against the World Trade Center in 2001, commuter trains in Madrid in 2004, and London's mass transit system in 2005 are still fresh in memory. There is no meaningful distinction to be drawn between Hamas extremists launching rockets against Israeli civilians and the Al Qaeda extremists who murdered noncombatant civilians in New York, Madrid and London.

Finally, Hamas has realized that their days are numbered and they have no longer have many friends in the world, except the puppets in Turkey and Qatar. Let's see how long before Hamas starts firing missiles again.....my guess within 6 hours after the cease fire begins.

If Hamas behaves and this cease fire lasts, then it is time for a review of the UNRWA. With weapons being stored at several UN facilities, it is clear that the UN has been partners with Hamas......comments from Boon, Turner and other ranking UN officials that, "we were so surprised to find weapons, we had no idea", just doesn't cut-it anymore. Since UNRWA's only charter is to support Palestinians, should be no surprise that they have been accomplices all along. Did you notice that always according to UN sources, "mostly civilians have been killed". I guess there are no terrorists firing missiles at Israel, just innocent women and children.

Western powers remember 100 years of WWI deflagration. China's leadership draw lessons from Western power occupation in the 19th century and invasion by Japanese Imperial forces at Qing dynasty twilight.

As far as homeland security, modern Chinese leadership study lessons learned from the past.

Imperial China was humiliated by Western powers and Japan because domestic conditions allowed that to happen. Using Dick Cheney's lexicon 'it was doable."
Modern Chinese political leadership are focusing (correctly) in two lessons from the past: economy and corruption.

The economy was the weakest link of Imperial China. Unlike Japan, the Qing dynasty rebuffed industrialization and integration to the global economy. The lack of an advanced industrial complex resulted into a military powerless country.

Public corruption was Qing's dynasty main ruling vice. One one hand, it kept millions of Chinese in poverty and illiteracy. That, in turn, allowed population control and domination. On the other hand, it made Chineses morally weak and vulnerable to addictions such as opium introduced by the British.

Perhaps the world will now assess the effect of Israel’s bombardments of Gaza, a defenseless strip, crowded with Palestinian refugees.

And the world will also assess the effect of the rockets launched by Hamas at Israel’s civilian population, which is shielded by a sophisticated and effective iron dome provided by our government.

Perhaps the world will then conclude that the forces were not equal, that Hamas was no match to Israel and that while the civilian Israeli population was defended and was essentially unscathed, the civilian Palestinian population of Gaza was devastated.

Perhaps the world will conclude that the presumed unwise course by Hamas notwithstanding, subjecting the defenseless, refugee population of Gaza, whose land and livelihood were taken away and given to another people, subjecting that population to a cruel blockade, destroying his nominal infrastructure, including its already inadequate sewer system, and exposing him to dangerous diseases, polluting his water resources, dismantling his power plants and bombing his schools and killing his children are more than the humanity can bear and should not be tolerated.

Perhaps the world will conclude that not only should Gaza be demilitarized but so should those who have perpetrated these injustices on it.

Perhaps, at long last, a just and permanent peace will be viewed as a better path to security than massive killings and destruction.

This mother is wise to protect her son's anonymity. My son was diagnosed as a preschooler with PDD-NOS. He could have gone either way, but a high IQ, good teachers, tenacious parents, and, undoubtedly, dumb luck, and he is no longer on the spectrum (or so say the formal tests). He has strong interests, a quirky sense of humor, and an affection for math. He benefits from social coaching, but not in a way that stands out as extreme. Nonetheless, because of his history, we've been turned down by elite private schools and some camps because they claim they are "just not equipped to deal with this". This, despite assurances from current teachers and doctors that there is nothing to "deal" with. Now we keep our mouths shut. It has never once come back to bite us.

We learned the hard way that the overwhelming majority of people (even those working in education) do not possess a nuanced understanding of what autism is. When those people land positions of authority, they can do real damage. Temple Grandin, in "The Autistic Brain", says that she believes 50% of people employed at Silicon Valley tech companies are on the spectrum, but they avoid the label for fear of being "ghettoized". Early labels are absolutely critical in order to access the carefully tailored instruction these children need prior or age 5, but older kids and adults who are borderline or "recovered" need to consider the risks of disclosure carefully.

Actually the US government was founded with a vast burden of debt for the Revolutionary War.

Just before WW1, the US was the world's greatest debtor. Its debt as very high, by any standard.

WW1 wiped out the position of those lenders, primarily Britain and France. They were forced by the War to liquidate to buy war supplies, then they borrowed even more. The US emerged from WW1 as the world's largest lender, all of it war debt.

Much of that war debt did not get paid. The US was very bitter about that. So when WW2 started, we made sure to be paid. By the end of that War, we owned the world.

That moment was not "normal" for the US, or the world.

Normal for the US, from 1787 on, has been what we are now.

Most often these days politicians get their direction from their donors and voter blocks, and voters don't hold politicians accountable for economic policy. Let's face it, economists lack credibility with the public, because economists have failed the public, in two ways that I know of.

1. Economists have failed to educate the public in terms that they can understand. Economists behave as if believe the average citizen doesn't have the smarts to understand even basic economics. (Ditto for climatologists.) This is an arrogant attitude, and it is not true. The lack of economic education of the population has placed society in a position where the public can be hoodwinked by spokespeople for the wealthy.

2. For the past four decades, the track record of the economy, and therefore the economists, has been abysmal in the United States. Economists set the bar for themselves very low. They consider 5% unemployment to be full employment. At that level the average worker has no bargaining power, so the wealth has been steadily shifting to the industry barons. For the past four decades, whenever there has been a whiff of inflation, economists have elevated unemployment to reduce consumer demand to tame inflation. This is bad economic policy, and is why the public rightfully concludes that economist don't know what they are doing.

The solution (aside: economists also have a deplorable lack of solutions, just a lot of griping) is to educate the public and improve your track record.

She has over 200 nuclear weapons and the unconditional backing of the most powerful and rich country in the history of the world (the U.S). On the other side, it is a pitiful resistance movement with primitive homemade rockets which have managed to cause 3 deaths after 3000 tries (a death rate of 0.01%). Cars are more deadly than these non-deadly rockets. As for the rhetoric, nobody should believe any rhetoric - whether noble or horrific - that comes from state actors or resistance fighters. If you have some time, compare the rhetoric of Irgun (Israel's pre-state terror (freedom fighter?) group with Hamas, the rhetoric isn't distinguishable. What we have is a structural issue: prisoner vs warden, kidnapped vs. captive, government vs resister, terrorist vs state and on and on. It is not good vs evil. When there was no Israel, there was Irgun; when there was no US there the colonial patriots (called terrorists by UK); and when there was no Palestine there was (is) Hamas.
